content.description: Stand start on slopey ledge and bear hug the amazing prow! Move the pads more to the right than you think.
content.protection: Depends on confidence bit bring a bunch of your not experienced.
content.location: The last big boulder before you reach the persons backyard. Please be quiet and respectful of choose to venture over there.

content.description: Start low on the right with a heel hook to stay on the arete. Traverse left till you reach the crack then use the crack to move to the shelf. Move across the shelf about 4ft then reach up to a good finish hold and topout.
content.location: Walk down the trail from the parking lot and go in-between the obvious flat top rock and the slab and the wedge is right there. The climbable face is facing the river.

content.description: Start on non-existent left hand undercling, right hand sidepull and do a cruxy first right hand bump to a sloper and do a few more moves to a tricky topout. Lower right hand start?
content.location: Right side of the "cave" with the big boulder underneath it.

content.description: Start on sidepull crimp left hand and right hand on good obvious edge and climb up on obvious edges. Sit start will be a hard V9/10/11+ project?!
content.protection: Two pads maybe. You might hit the adjacent rock when you go for the sloper up top.
content.location: Behind the emerald triangle at the river boulders in the NorCal bouldering guide.

content.description: Halfway between Emerald Triangle and the Cottonwood Slabs is a south-facing "cave." Start on the outside on a rail and climb the roof crack INTO the cave. The crack widens and you can tunnel your way up the chimney and out it's tiny exit. The catch is there is no way to flip around and you must climb the entire 10' chimney upsidedown, feet first. It is significantly harder than "The Warden," the benchmark V8 offwidth in Vedauwoo.
content.location: Halfway between Emerald Triangle and the Cottonwood Slabs is a south-facing "cave."

content.description: Swim to the base of the arete. Once on the first hold you can reach out of the water traverse left and climb up the center of the slab.
content.protection: Water level is best around June but the rock can get really hot midday.

content.description:
Smooth river rock traverse. Start low on right and finish at top on left. Just use the holds on the face not the top.

Short but fun slippery slab traverse.
content.location: Take the trail down from the parking area go just past the close flat top rock and you should see the climbable face of the rock facing down river.

content.description: Overhanging triangular face rock. About 25ft to the right of Firestarter. Slippery rock with mantle finish.
content.location: Start at the lowest part of the left side, move up and use the crack to move across, then campus or toe hook right side to reach flat shelf on ride side. Mantle finish.

content.description: Start on slopey left hand knob and right hand low undercling and squeeze your way up to a easy but insecure slippery arete topout. Comparable to climbing on someone's marble countertop its that slick
content.protection: 3 pads. If your feet blow off the insanely slick feet you might cut up on the sharp rocks in the pit.
content.location: in the obvious cluster of giant boulders on the other side of the first easy slab

content.description: Start on the right and traverse up left into the top out of Firestarter
Sit start on jug And climb through the obvious roof. If someone digs it out with a shovel it will be more fun.

A short, but techy problem just left of the Cottonwood trees formed as two boulders abut each other creating a small cave. Start in the back of the alcove and top out the slab. It's usually done with a feet-first beta with a bomber knee-bar and offwith style pivot. With the right technique, it should be just about three or four moves. It can be done as a standard boulder cranking, but it's not as graceful and a good deal more work.
content.location: Just left (north) of the cottonwood slabs. West facing alcove/cave

content.description: Sit start on two low sidepulls and compression slap or use scrunchy lockoff into the stand.
content.location: The triangle Arete problem facing the river.

climbs.name: Crescent arete.
climbs.fa: ? Post boulder tilt FA: Chris Terry?

content.description: Sit start right hand crimpy knob. Left hand as low as you can and traverse the sloper arete. Super scrunchy low sit (V8/9?)
content.location: Obvious arete lip traverse next to firestarter.

content.description: Stand on the slab and use the crimps to move your feet up and throw to the finish hold. The topout is solid but the down climb is less than ideal.
content.location: Prickly pear boulder side facing the river.
